units.title: Tissue Collection and Storage
units.text: Collect primary human tissue pieces, separated by biopsy site and/or tissue type (i.e., normal and tumor tissue) in 45 ml of ice-cold adDMEM/F12+++ medium in 50-ml conical tubes. (Optional) Add 10 µM ROCK inhibitor to adDMEM/F12+++ medium to increase cell survival. Keep tissue samples in this medium at 4 °C until the start of the isolation.
units.rationale: This is an actionable step for collecting and preserving tissue to maintain cell viability before organoid establishment.

units.title: Removal of Non-Epithelial Tissue
units.text: Assess whether obtained tissue pieces consist purely of epithelium or if they also contain fat or muscle tissue. If so, remove non-epithelial components as much as possible using surgical scissors or scalpels and forceps under a dissection microscope.
units.rationale: This step ensures purity of epithelial tissue for successful organoid formation by eliminating contaminating stromal material.

units.title: Tissue Fragmentation
units.text: Mince the tissue into small fragments of 1–3 mm3 in a 10-cm cell culture dish using surgical scissors or scalpels.
units.rationale: This is a critical procedural step to prepare tissue for enzymatic digestion during organoid generation.

units.title: Enzymatic Digestion
units.text: Digest the tissue (from Step 3) as appropriate based on the tumor type (Table 1). Carefully monitor digestion, and for <2-h incubations, mix contents every 10–15 min by shaking vigorously and by pipetting the mixture up and down using a P1000 pipette.
units.rationale: This step describes a precise, time-sensitive procedure for dissociating tissue into single cells or clusters for plating.

units.title: Cell Filtration and Centrifugation
units.text: Wash once by topping up with 10 ml of adDMEM/F12+++ medium, and centrifuge at 200g for 5 min at 4 °C. Resuspend the pellet in 10 ml of adDMEM/F12+++ medium, and filter using a 100-µm cell strainer. Centrifuge the resuspended and ﬁltered cells at 200g for 5 min at 4 °C.
units.rationale: This sequence ensures removal of debris and isolation of viable cell populations for organoid plating.

units.title: Plating in ECM Hydrogel
units.text: Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in BME or Matrigel. BME should be kept on ice to prevent it from solidifying; thus, work quickly. The amount of BME depends on the size of the pellet. Approximately 10,000 cells should be plated in 40 µl of BME. Plate the BME containing organoids on the bottom of pre-heated 24-well suspension cell culture plates in drops of ~10 µl each.
units.rationale: This is a key procedural step for 3D culture initiation, specifying critical parameters like cell density and ECM handling.

units.title: BME Solidification
units.text: Place the culture plate into a humidiﬁed incubator at 37 °C and 5% (vol/vol) CO2 for 20–30 min to let the BME solidify.
units.rationale: This step ensures proper ECM gelation before medium addition, which is essential for organoid formation.

units.title: Medium Addition to BME Droplets
units.text: Once the BME drops are solidiﬁed (30–60 min), ﬂip the plate and carefully add 500 µl of organoid medium to each well. Do not add medium directly on top of the BME drops, as this might disrupt the droplets.
units.rationale: This instruction prevents physical disruption of the ECM structure critical for organoid growth.

units.title: Organoid Splitting Using TrypLE
units.text: To aid in the removal of BME, top the volume up with 10 ml of ice-cold adDMEM/F12+++ medium. Centrifuge organoids at 200g for 5 min at 4 °C. Aspirate the supernatant, and split organoids using either TrypLE (for head and neck and compact breast, colon, pancreatic and liver organoids) or mechanical disruption... For TrypLE-based cell dissociation, resuspend the pellet in 1 ml of TrypLE, pipette up and down and incubate at 37 °C until organoids fall apart.
units.rationale: This provides a detailed, actionable protocol for passaging organoids using enzymatic dissociation with critical timing and technique.

units.title: Organoid Freezing
units.text: Add the required volume of cell-freezing medium, and pipette up and down using a P1000 pipette to properly resuspend the organoids. 500 μl of freezing medium should be used for four ‘original’ wells with organoids of a 24-well cell culture plate. Per sterile cryogenic vial, add 500 µl of freezing medium with the resuspended organoids. Place the cryogenic vial into a freezing container. Store the freezing container with the samples at –80 °C. After storage at –80 °C for 24 h, remove the vials from the freezing container, and transfer them to the liquid nitrogen tank (approximately –180 °C).
units.rationale: This is a standardized, step-by-step protocol for cryopreserving organoids with precise volumes and temperature controls.
